content.text: This fact sheet sets out our position on the presence of reinforced autoclaved aerated concrete (RAAC) in the NHS. RAAC is a lightweight form of precast concrete, frequently used in public sector buildings in the UK from the mid-1950s to the mid-1990s.
A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said:
“We have inherited a broken NHS, with many hospitals in a state of disrepair, meaning patients have not been able to access the care they so desperately need.
“We are committed to fully removing RAAC from the NHS estate whilst working to keep facilities open, with patient safety at the forefront.
“Repairing and rebuilding our crumbling hospital estate is a vital part of our ambition to create an NHS that is fit for the future through our Ten-Year Health Plan.”
